p: The one consensus good year for populations was 1975/1976, when 9% ( n = 16) of moths experienced population explosions (butterflies could not be considered because data collection did not start until the following year) and none crashed. The climate in 1975 was relatively dry, with the summer of 1976 being extremely hot and dry ( table 1 and figure 3 c, d) with a drought index nearly double the median over the study period (figures 2 a, 3 d and table 1). Subsequently, significant numbers of Lepidoptera (54 of 207 species, 26%) experienced population crashes between 1976 and 1977. However, while 1976/1977 was the year with the most Lepidoptera crashes (54 of 207 species), a few Lepidoptera (four species) still experienced population explosions in the same year. This suggests that there can be cumulative effects, and that some climatic extremes may generate opposite direct and lagged effects (in this case, explosion followed by crash).
